title: What do people from Ireland think of Boston? - Quora

response.answer_text: The first few times I visited Boston, I wasn’t a fan. I don’t know what I was expecting, maybe something similar to Dublin. I was set back by the aggressive tipping culture, the constant rush, the crazy drivers and the fact that parts of Boston (ie Woburn) were still dry areas. I didn’t necessarily see it as a friendly city, and I quickly realised that the American definition of an “old city” was quite different to the the Irish definition. This was before the Big Dig: a loud ugly metal motorway cutting through the city looked incongruous. But little by little, I came to love Boston. It has many charming gardens and parks and a wonderful arboretum near the centre of town. The humour is very sarcastic and similar to back home - Bostonians get slagging and irony. The museums are great, the aquarium is fantastic and it’s a city with a proper history: Boston is ground zero of the United States after all. The bars and restaurants are good. It’s a student city with real life to it. It has an abundance of lectures, concerts, shows and exhibits to see. And unlike many cities in America, Boston has a proper public transport system. So yeah, Boston. It grows on you.

What do people from Ireland think of Boston? Nothing in particular I’d reckon - it’s just another city in a foreign country thousands of miles away. Other than folks who’ve been there or have connections there, it’s not exactly a hot topic here - bigger/more famous US cities like NYC or LA would probably be more into the household name status. Plenty of people touristing to the US do visit the place, mind you.
